articles.headline: Time Warner Ends Talks With Meredith and Will Spin Off Time Inc. Into Separate Company
articles.snippet: The primary sticking point between the two companies was the fate of several titles, including Time and Sports Illustrated, which Time Warner wanted to shed but which Meredith was not eager to acquire.
articles.abstract: The primary sticking point between the two companies was the fate of several titles, including Time and Sports Illustrated, which Time Warner wanted to shed but which Meredith was not eager to acquire.
articles.lead_paragraph: 9:14 p.m. | Updated What do you do with a group of celebrated magazines that no one seems to want?

articles.headline: Syrian Rebels in Golan Region Hold U.N. Peacekeeping Team
articles.snippet: Syria’s civil war entangled the peacekeeping operation in the disputed Golan Heights area Wednesday, when 30 armed fighters for the insurgency detained a group of peacekeepers.
articles.abstract: Syria’s civil war entangled the peacekeeping operation in the disputed Golan Heights area Wednesday, when 30 armed fighters for the insurgency detained a group of peacekeepers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Insurgent fighters from Syria seized a group of United Nations troops on patrol in the disputed Golan Heights region between Syria and Israel on Wednesday and threatened to treat them as prisoners of war, an abrupt escalation in the Syrian conflict that entangled international peacekeepers for the first time.
articles.byline: By Rick Gladstone and Alan Cowell

articles.headline: Subscribing to Office, Now and Forever
articles.snippet: This year with Microsoft Office, it’s not what the features are, but how you pay for them. There are two ways to subscribe.
articles.abstract: This year with Microsoft Office, it’s not what the features are, but how you pay for them. There are two ways to subscribe.
articles.lead_paragraph: It must be tough to be on the Microsoft Office team. Year after year, you’re given the same assignment: add new features to Word, Excel, PowerPoint and Outlook. New features that people will pay for, but that won’t turn Microsoft’s cash cow into a bloated, sloshing mess.

articles.headline: With Positions to Fill, Employers Wait for Perfection
articles.snippet: Many companies remain reluctant to hire, stringing job applicants along for weeks or months before they make a decision.
articles.abstract: Many companies remain reluctant to hire, stringing job applicants along for weeks or months before they make a decision.
articles.lead_paragraph: American employers have a variety of job vacancies, piles of cash and countless well-qualified candidates. But despite a slowly improving economy, many companies remain reluctant to actually hire, stringing job applicants along for weeks or months before they make a decision.

articles.headline: Arkansas Adopts a Ban on Abortions After 12 Weeks
articles.snippet: A law enacted Wednesday contradicts the 24-week limit established by the Supreme Court, and abortion rights groups have promised a suit to block the ban before it goes into effect.
articles.abstract: A law enacted Wednesday contradicts the 24-week limit established by the Supreme Court, and abortion rights groups have promised a suit to block the ban before it goes into effect.
articles.lead_paragraph: Arkansas adopted what is by far the country’s most restrictive ban on abortion on Wednesday — at 12 weeks of pregnancy, when a fetal heartbeat can typically be detected by abdominal ultrasound.

articles.headline: Boeing Plan to Test Fixes on 787 Nears Approval
articles.snippet: Battery tests on the 787 Dreamliner could begin next week, officials said, but federal regulators could still demand changes in the proposed design changes if problems develop.
articles.abstract: Battery tests on the 787 Dreamliner could begin next week, officials said, but federal regulators could still demand changes in the proposed design changes if problems develop.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Aviation Administration is close to approving tests of Boeing’s approach to fixing the batteries on its 787 jets, and the tests could begin next week, federal and industry officials said Wednesday.

articles.headline: Face-Lift at Facebook, to Keep Its Users Engaged
articles.snippet: Facebook plans to announce a substantial redesign of its News Feed — a makeover aimed both at keeping users glued to the social network and luring more advertising dollars.
articles.abstract: Facebook plans to announce a substantial redesign of its News Feed — a makeover aimed both at keeping users glued to the social network and luring more advertising dollars.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook plans to announce on Thursday a substantial redesign of its News Feed — a makeover aimed at both keeping users glued to the social network and luring more advertising dollars.

articles.headline: Charity Takes Gun Lobby Closer to Its Quarry
articles.snippet: The Congressional Sportsmen’s Foundation allows its donors to mix with lawmakers and press issues important mainly to the firearms industry.
articles.abstract: The Congressional Sportsmen’s Foundation allows its donors to mix with lawmakers and press issues important mainly to the firearms industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a Monday evening in early February, two months into a national debate over gun violence after the massacre at a Connecticut elementary school, representatives of the firearms industry were wining and dining lawmakers in Washington.

articles.headline: Wall Street Ties in a Prospect for Deputy at the S.E.C.
articles.snippet: As Mary Jo White confronts scrutiny over her ties to big Wall Street firms, a leading candidate to be her enforcement chief — Andrew J. Ceresney — has trod a similar path.
articles.abstract: As Mary Jo White confronts scrutiny over her ties to big Wall Street firms, a leading candidate to be her enforcement chief — Andrew J. Ceresney — has trod a similar path.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mary Jo White, who appears set to become a top Wall Street regulator, is seeking to allay skepticism about her spins through the revolving door between government service and private practice.
articles.byline: By PETER LATTMAN and BEN PROTESS

articles.headline: A Leader Cries, ‘I Am Chávez,’ as U.S. Seeks Policy Clues
articles.snippet: As President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela neared death, Vice President Nicolás Maduro’s imitations of him became apparent. Less clear are Mr. Maduro’s intentions toward the United States.
articles.abstract: As President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela neared death, Vice President Nicolás Maduro’s imitations of him became apparent. Less clear are Mr. Maduro’s intentions toward the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — In the weeks leading up to his mentor’s death, Vice President Nicolás Maduro’s imitations of President Hugo Chávez became ever more apparent.
articles.byline: By William Neuman and Ginger Thompson

articles.headline: A Respite in Efforts by Wal-Mart in New York
articles.snippet: The company has pulled back after its push to open a store in the East New York section of Brooklyn fell through.
articles.abstract: The company has pulled back after its push to open a store in the East New York section of Brooklyn fell through.
articles.lead_paragraph: After losing a battle in September to open its first store in New York City, Wal-Mart Stores appears to have scaled back its efforts to gain a foothold in the nation’s largest city.
articles.byline: By Steven Greenhouse and Stephanie Clifford

articles.headline: C.I.A.’s History Poses Hurdles for an Obama Nominee
articles.snippet: John O. Brennan’s first challenge at the agency where he worked for 25 years may be confronting a sweeping indictment of its former interrogation program.
articles.abstract: John O. Brennan’s first challenge at the agency where he worked for 25 years may be confronting a sweeping indictment of its former interrogation program.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — John O. Brennan’s first difficult challenge at the C.I.A. may not be confronting the agency’s future, but its past.

articles.headline: New Sanctions on North Korea Pass in Unified U.N. Vote
articles.snippet: A resolution in response to North Korea’s nuclear test last month, negotiated between the United States and China, won unanimous approval from the United Nations Security Council.
articles.abstract: A resolution in response to North Korea’s nuclear test last month, negotiated between the United States and China, won unanimous approval from the United Nations Security Council.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ignoring threats of retaliation, the United Nations Security Council ordered new economic sanctions against North Korea on Thursday for its third nuclear test last month, unanimously approving a resolution that the United States negotiated with China, the North’s greatest protector.
articles.byline: By Rick Gladstone and David E. Sanger
